nodes.name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act
nodes.description: Federal law that requires financial institutions to explain their information-sharing practices to their customers and to safeguard sensitive data. It includes the Financial Privacy Rule, Safeguards Rule, and pretexting provisions.

nodes.name: Financial Privacy Rule (Reg P)
nodes.description: Governs the collection and disclosure of customers' personal financial information.

nodes.name: Safeguards Rule (Reg S-P)
nodes.description: Requires financial institutions to develop a secure information security program.

nodes.name: Pretexting Provisions
nodes.description: Prohibits obtaining customer information by false pretenses.

nodes.name: Breach Notification Rule (2024)
nodes.description: Requires notification to the FTC and consumers for breaches affecting 500+ people.

nodes.heading: Initial Privacy Notice
nodes.text: Provide a clear and conspicuous notice that accurately reflects privacy policies and practices.

nodes.heading: Prohibition on Pretexting
nodes.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain or attempt to obtain customer information of a financial institution by false pretenses.

nodes.heading: Breach Notification
nodes.text: Notify the FTC as soon as possible and no later than 30 days after discovery of a security event involving 500 or more consumers.
Designate a Qualified Individual to oversee the information security program.
Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for any individual accessing customer information.
Implement procedures for the secure disposal of customer information (shredding/wiping).
Provide initial privacy notice to customers no later than when the relationship is established.
Provide a reasonable opportunity and method for consumers to opt out of third-party sharing.
Establish procedures to verify the identity of a person seeking information (Identity Verification).
Notify the FTC of any security event affecting 500 or more consumers within 30 days.
Oversee service providers to ensure they maintain appropriate safeguards.

nodes.name: Financial Institution
nodes.description: Any institution significantly engaged in financial activities (Banks

nodes.name: Customer
nodes.description: A consumer who has a continuing relationship with a financial institution.

nodes.name: Consumer
nodes.description: An individual who obtains a financial product or service (broader than customer).

nodes.name: Employee
nodes.description: Staff member of the financial institution who handles NPI.

nodes.name: Nonpublic Personal Information
nodes.description: Personally identifiable financial information that is not publicly available.

nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Information
nodes.description: Information that can identify an individual.

nodes.name: Account Information
nodes.description: Specific details regarding financial accounts.

nodes.name: Multi-Factor Authentication
nodes.description: Authentication requiring two or more factors (Knowledge

nodes.name: Encryption (Transit/Rest)
nodes.description: Cryptographic protection of data while stored or moving across networks.

nodes.name: Security Awareness Training
nodes.description: Regular training for employees on security risks and pretexting.

nodes.name: Secure Disposal
nodes.description: Cross-cut shredding or secure wiping of media containing NPI.
Civil penalties of up to $100
Criminal penalties including imprisonment for up to 5 years for knowing violations.
Cease and Desist orders requiring the stopping of illegal practices.

nodes.name: Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
nodes.description: Designated individual responsible for overseeing and implementing the information security program.

nodes.name: Board of Directors
nodes.description: Governing body that must receive annual reports on the information security program.

nodes.name: Cloud Infrastructure Provider
nodes.description: Third-party maintaining customer data (e.g. AWS Azure).

nodes.name: Payment Processor
nodes.description: Third-party processing credit card transactions.

nodes.name: Annual Security Risk Assessment
nodes.description: Written assessment identifying foreseeable internal and external risks.

nodes.name: Pretexting
nodes.description: Social engineering attempts to obtain NPI by false pretenses.

nodes.name: Phishing
nodes.description: Deceptive emails targeting employee credentials.

nodes.name: Unauthorized Access
nodes.description: Internal or external actors accessing NPI without permission.

nodes.name: Customer Database
nodes.description: SQL database containing NPI (SSN

nodes.name: Employee Laptop
nodes.description: Endpoint devices used to access financial data.

nodes.name: Initial Privacy Notice
nodes.details: Provided at account opening describing data sharing practices.

nodes.name: Annual Privacy Notice
nodes.details: Provided annually to existing customers describing changes.

nodes.name: Toll-Free Number
nodes.details: 1-800 number for customers to call and opt-out.

nodes.name: Detached Form
nodes.details: Mail-in form included with the privacy notice.

nodes.name: External Marketing Firm
nodes.details: Third party company not owned by the financial institution used for marketing.

nodes.name: Hypothetical Breach Event
nodes.description: Unauthorized acquisition of unencrypted NPI involving >500 consumers.

nodes.name: Phone Pretexting
nodes.description: Caller impersonating account holder to bypass verification.

nodes.name: Email Spear Phishing
nodes.description: Targeted email to executive to install malware.

rels.description: The 2024 Rule requires designating a Qualified Individual.
Financial Institutions must provide an initial privacy notice at account opening.
GLBA explicitly prohibits obtaining customer info via phone pretexting.
GLBA prohibits obtaining customer info via fraudulent statements (phishing).
Breach affecting >500 individuals triggers the requirement to notify the FTC.
GLBA requires overseeing cloud providers who handle NPI.
GLBA requires overseeing payment processors who handle NPI.
Multi-factor authentication mitigates the risk of pretexting/unauthorized access.
QI must report annually to the Board on the status of the security program.
Assessment identifies pretexting as a key social engineering threat.
Assessment identifies phishing as a key cybersecurity threat.
Risk assessment must evaluate risks to customer databases.
Risk assessment must evaluate risks to employee devices.
Privacy notice must detail the toll-free number for opting out.
Opt-out rights apply to sharing with non-affiliated marketing firms.
